articles.headline: Growing Economic Crisis Threatens the Idea of One Europe
articles.snippet: An emergency meeting of European leaders raised the very worries it was intended to calm: that the crisis threatens to split Europe into rival camps.
articles.abstract: An emergency meeting of European leaders raised the very worries it was intended to calm: that the crisis threatens to split Europe into rival camps.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The leaders of the European Union gathered Sunday in Brussels in an emergency summit meeting that seemed to highlight the very worries it was designed to calm: that the world economic crisis has unleashed forces threatening to split Europe into rival camps.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Ukraine Teeters as Citizens Blame Banks and Government
articles.snippet: Factories and services are faltering, the currency is wilting and a government default seems possible, posing a real threat to other European economies.
articles.abstract: Factories and services are faltering, the currency is wilting and a government default seems possible, posing a real threat to other European economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine  Steel and chemical factories, once the muscle of Ukraine’s economy, are dismissing thousands of workers. Cities have had days without heat or water because they cannot pay their bills, and Kiev’s subway service is being threatened. Lines are sprouting at banks, the currency is wilting and even a government default seems possible.

articles.headline: Food Magazines Begin to Consider Cooks’ Budgets
articles.snippet: As upscale food magazines like Gourmet and Food & Wine try to survive the shaky economy, it is out with the truffles, in with the button mushrooms.
articles.abstract: As upscale food magazines like Gourmet and Food & Wine try to survive the shaky economy, it is out with the truffles, in with the button mushrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: After covering eating trends that have included haute pub food, exotic fruits like yuzu, and restaurants that dehydrated, foamed and froze everything from meat to dessert, upscale food magazines are writing about an even more unexpected topic: cheap home eating.

articles.headline: ‘South Park,’ a Vision and a Payoff
articles.snippet: While Hollywood and network studios are struggling to find the future, the creators of the show “South Park” have created a visionary broadcasting model.
articles.abstract: While Hollywood and network studios are struggling to find the future, the creators of the show “South Park” have created a visionary broadcasting model.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the boy island that is “South Park,” Comedy Central’s long-running series, adult supervision is more often tolerated than heeded. For the most part, Stan, Kyle, Cartman and Kenny seem to listen carefully and then do what they want.

articles.headline: Microsoft Mapping Course to a Jetsons-Style Future
articles.snippet: As personal computer sales stagnate, Microsoft and its longtime partner, Intel, are looking to diversify into sophisticated artificial intelligence products.
articles.abstract: As personal computer sales stagnate, Microsoft and its longtime partner, Intel, are looking to diversify into sophisticated artificial intelligence products.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.  Meet Laura, the virtual personal assistant for those of us who cannot afford a human one.

articles.headline: India Maintains Sense of Optimism and Growth
articles.snippet: Some say the country’s bureaucracy and its protectionist polices have kept it insulated from the global downturn.
articles.abstract: Some say the country’s bureaucracy and its protectionist polices have kept it insulated from the global downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  While most of the world grapples with a crippling financial crisis and a recession, optimism reigns in much of India as its economy continues to grow.

articles.headline: Copyright Challenge for Sites That Excerpt
articles.snippet: As copyrighted material is excerpted online, some owners would rather have clicks than credit.
articles.abstract: As copyrighted material is excerpted online, some owners would rather have clicks than credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the popular New York business blog Silicon Alley Insider quoted a quarter of Peggy Noonan’s Wall Street Journal column in mid-February, the editor added a caveat at the end: “We thank Dow Jones in advance for allowing us to bring it to you.”

articles.headline: U.S. Is Said to Offer Another $30 Billion in Funds to A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The government also agreed to loosen the terms of its first loan to the insurer, which will report a $62 billion quarterly loss on Monday, people involved in the discussions said.
articles.abstract: The government also agreed to loosen the terms of its first loan to the insurer, which will report a $62 billion quarterly loss on Monday, people involved in the discussions said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government agreed Sunday night to provide an additional $30 billion in taxpayer money to the American International Group and loosen the terms of its huge loan to the insurer, which is preparing to report a $62 billion loss on Monday, the biggest quarterly loss in history, people involved in the discussions said.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley’s Chinese Land Scandal
articles.snippet: In a S.E.C. filing, the bank said it had fired an executive in its China real estate division after uncovering evidence that he might have bribed foreign officials.
articles.abstract: In a S.E.C. filing, the bank said it had fired an executive in its China real estate division after uncovering evidence that he might have bribed foreign officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Since the height of China’s property boom, Morgan Stanley’s huge real estate deals here have been the envy of the industry. Then, scandal hit.

articles.headline: Obama Pick Gets a 2nd Chance on Health Care
articles.snippet: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius’s efforts to forge bipartisan consensus on health care have rarely succeeded in Kansas.
articles.abstract: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius’s efforts to forge bipartisan consensus on health care have rarely succeeded in Kansas.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan.  In Kansas, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius is known as a Democrat who can deal with Republicans, a necessity in a state where the opposition party dominates both houses of the Legislature.

articles.headline: Steep Market Drops Highlight Despair Over Rescue Efforts
articles.snippet: The Dow’s fall below 7,000 for the first time since 1997 follows a huge loss by A.I.G.
articles.abstract: The Dow’s fall below 7,000 for the first time since 1997 follows a huge loss by A.I.G.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fears that the world’s economies are even weaker than had been thought ricocheted around the globe on Monday as investors from Hong Kong to London to New York bailed out of stocks.
